ViewDef.Title: ESXi High Memory Trend
ViewDef.Description: Trend line of ESXi high memory utilization. Because the very purpose memory is cache, having 100% utilization is better than 99%. However, at 99.1% the ballooning process kicks in. This increases the risk of swapping and compression, which in turn increases the chance of memory contention.

ViewDef.Title: VM CPU Size Distribution
ViewDef.Description:
Absolute distribution of VMs vCPU. Minimize the large VMs, especially those exceeding the size of the underlying ESXi CPU socket core, as they likely create performance and capacity problem.
Be careful of system on a chip packaging, where multiple core complex are packaged together in a single socket. This results in NUMA effect as the complex do not share L3 cache.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Hosts Performance
ViewDef.Description: List of ESXi hosts and their key performance. Because it focuses on proactive monitoring, the worst counter is shown. The Performance SLA uses a high standard, hence both the 95th percentile and worst are shown. 95th is used instead of 99th because there can be false positive from Network counter.

ViewDef.Title: Datastore Performance List
ViewDef.Description: List of datastores, their key performance and configuration that are meant to be consistent. Local datastores are not excluded. Because it focuses on proactive monitoring, the worst counter is shown.

ViewDef.Title: VM CPU Ready Distribution
ViewDef.Description:
Distribution of VMs by their CPU Ready. It's using the 20-second Peak metric, not the average metric.
It's showing the 99th percentile, and not the peak. This balances between false positive (showing outlier) and too late. 99th is chosen and not 95th as it's designed for early warning.
The bar chart is segregated into different buckets. Each bucket is color coded, showing different threshold.

Property.name: localizedAttributeName
Property.value: CPU|Peak vCPU Ready within collection cycle (%)

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Power Management
ViewDef.Description: The power management setting at ESXi level. Compare with the value at BIOS level

ViewDef.Title: Guest OS Utilization List
ViewDef.Description:
While the object is VM, what is being sized is the Guest OS inside VM. The external footprint is not relevant in this context.
List of powered on VMs and their capacity utilization. For memory, Guest OS metrics are used. Notice the metrics use different percentile, that is appropriate for the metric.
Creation Date is added as new VM tends to be lowly utilized.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Port Group MAC Address Change
ViewDef.Description: Count of distributed port group that allows network MAC address to be changed. Minimize this as it allows MAC address impersonation. If allowed, ESXi host does not drop the packet when the Guest OS MAC address does not match the VM MAC address.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Cluster HA Status
ViewDef.Description:
Relative distribution of clusters High Availability status. Expect all clusters to have HA enabled. HA protects VMs in the event of ESXi host failure.
True = enabled.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Cluster Utilization
ViewDef.Description:
List of clusters and their utilization. The context is capacity management, not performance. 95th percentile is chosen. Note this is not a projection, so it's not looking into the future.
The Performance metric is affected, as it shows the 99th percentile. Capacity management should ignore outlier, different from Performance management.

ViewDef.Title: VM Performance List
ViewDef.Description: List of VMs and their key performance indicators. Because it focuses on proactive monitoring, the worst counter is shown. The default shows data from the worst 5 minute in the last 24 hours. As this focuses on performance, powered off VMs are excluded.

ViewDef.Title: VM Memory Distribution
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of VMs by memory.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi on Maintenance Mode
ViewDef.Description: List of ESXi hosts on maintenance mode. ESXi under maintenance is not contributing to the pool of resource, hence this mode is not a normal mode in operations.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Cluster Memory Reservation
ViewDef.Description:
Relative distribution of clusters memory reservation. Expect to have 0 or minimal reservation, as they impact capacity.
Memory should use a lower threshold than what CPU has as memory is sticky. The reservation takes effect despite Guest OS no longer touches the page.

ViewDef.Title: VM Virtual Disks counts
ViewDef.Description: Absolute distribution of VMs by their number of virtual disks. Minimize those with many virtual disks as it creates islands of disk space.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi NTP Running
ViewDef.Description: Count of ESXi hosts where Network Time Protocol (NTP) is not set. NTP is critical to ensure all times are synchronous.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by Memory Size
ViewDef.Description:
Absolute distribution of ESXi hosts, by their memory size in GB. Keep the combination minimal for ease of operations. Minimize small hosts as they are relatively more expensive when all costs are considered (software, people, facilities). To apply a threshold, go to filter tab.
Typical ESXi sports 512 GB RAM. Using typical 4:1 Ratio, this gives around 128 vCPU before the Memory being overcommitted.
This view is used in dashboard: Configuration \ ESXi
Source: vSphere Adapter

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by Versions
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of ESXi versions. Keep the total number of versions minimal as a high number complicate operations. ESXi hosts in the same cluster should have identical configuration.

ViewDef.Title: VM with Hot Add CPU
ViewDef.Description: Count of VMs with hot add CPU enabled. While dynamic configuration is a powerful feature, it increases complexity in capacity and performance management.

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by CPU to add
ViewDef.Description: Count of VMs, grouped by the amount of vCPU to be added, as per Capacity Engine recommendation. Give the engine time enough predictable cycles for better prediction. A VM with month-end cycle will need 3 months.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by NIC Count
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of ESXi physical network card speed. Use 25 Gb NIC or higher for faster performance, especially if ESXi runs distributed storage. Keep the total number of combination minimal as a high number complicate operations. Also, check ESXi with < 10 Gb NIC.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Network Properties
ViewDef.Description: List the summary of the network properties associated with the Distributed Virtual Switch for the selected Host System in your environment.

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by CPU Share
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of VM CPU shares in a specific container (e.g. Cluster, Resource Pool, ESXi). A VM Share impacts the amount of CPU time given to it when there is not enough for all virtual machines in the cluster. This number needs to match the class of service, so ideally 1 number per cluster as a cluster should only deliver 1 class of service (e.g. Gold cluster).

ViewDef.Title: vSphere VMs Context
ViewDef.Description: List of VMs and their relevant information

ViewDef.Title: VM Disk Latency Distribution
ViewDef.Description:
Distribution of VMs by their Disk Write Latency. It's using the 20-second Peak metric, not the average metric.
It's showing the 99th percentile, and not the peak. This balances between false positive (showing outlier) and too late. 99th is chosen and not 95th as it's designed for early warning.
The bar chart is segregated into different buckets. Each bucket is color coded, showing different threshold. Write latency is used as read latency tends to be much lower due to cache.

Property.name: localizedAttributeName
Property.value: Virtual Disk|Peak Latency within collection cycle (ms)

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by Reclaimable Disk
ViewDef.Description: Count of powered off VMs, grouped by the amount of disk that can be reclaimed, as per Capacity Engine recommendation.

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by Memory Share
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of VM memory shares in a specific container (e.g. Cluster, Resource Pool, ESXi). A VM Share impacts the amount of memory given to it when there is not enough for all virtual machines in the cluster. This number needs to match the class of service, so ideally 1 number per cluster as a cluster should only deliver 1 class of service (e.g. Gold cluster).

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by CPU Socket
ViewDef.Description: Count of clusters with 4 or more CPU sockets. Avoid 4 sockets due to NUMA. Use 1 - 2 sockets with high core counts instead. For low cost, use single socket with high core counts.

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by Reclaimable Memory
ViewDef.Description: Count of VMs, grouped by the amount of RAM that can be reclaimed, as per Capacity Engine recommendation. Give the engine time enough predictable cycles for better prediction. A VM with month-end cycle will need 3 months.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Data Center Network List
ViewDef.Description: List of vSphere data centers with networking metrics

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by CPU GHz
ViewDef.Description: Absolute distribution of ESXi hosts, by their CPU size in GHz. Keep them minimal. Also, pay attention to small hosts as they have relatively higher overhead, hence less optimized. To change the threshold, go to filter tab.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Data Centers Inventory
ViewDef.Description:
List of vSphere data centers. Only basic information is provided as this view is designed to be used in as a selector (filter).
The vCenter column is required as the cluster name in VMware-based cloud is not unique.

ViewDef.Title: VM Configured Size Summary
ViewDef.Description: A summary table showing the average, largest and smallest VM in the environment by their configured size.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by Hardware Model
ViewDef.Description: Displays the aggregated data about the different ESXI models for the host system for the host systems in your environment.

ViewDef.Title: Guest OS List of Services
ViewDef.Description:
List of Operating System processes or services, along with basic information.
Note: this requires Service Discovery adapter.

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by Memory Reservation
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of VM memory reservation. A VM reservation impacts DRS behaviour and reduce Capacity, hence resulting in less optimal environment.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Cluster Distribution by CPU Reservation
ViewDef.Description: Absolute distribution of vSphere clusters CPU reservation. Expect to have 0 or minimal reservation, as they impact capacity.

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by Snapshots Age
ViewDef.Description: Count of snapshots grouped by age. Snapshot should only be used as protection of change. Once change is successful, snapshot does more harm as it impacts performance and take up space. Delete them before they are forgotten.

ViewDef.Title: VM with no Guest counters
ViewDef.Description: Count of VMs without the Guest OS counters collected. Missing Guest OS counter reduces the accuracy of memory rightsizing recommendation. The view filters out VMs that are not running as we can't determine if Guest OS is working or not.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Cluster Resource Management
ViewDef.Description: List of vSphere Clusters with relevant information for CPU and memory resources analysis.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by Core Counts
ViewDef.Description:
Absolute distribution of ESXi hosts, by their physical CPU core. Keep the combination minimal for ease of operations. Minimize small hosts as they are relatively more expensive when all costs are considered (software, people, facilities). To apply a threshold, go to filter tab.
Typical ESXi sports 1 TB RAM. Using typical 4:1 Ratio for RAM:vCPU, this gives around 256 vCPU before the Memory being overcommitted.

ViewDef.Title: VM with Hot Remove CPU
ViewDef.Description: Count of VMs with hot remove CPU enabled. While dynamic configuration is a powerful feature, it increases complexity in capacity and performance management.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Port Group Promiscuous Mode Allowed
ViewDef.Description: Count of distributed port groups that allow promiscuous mode. Minimize this for security reason, and only use for the use case it's designed for.

ViewDef.Title: VM CPU Allocation Trend
ViewDef.Description: Trend line of VM growth. It shows both the powered on and powered off, to see the relative movement over time

ViewDef.Title: Local Datastore with VM
ViewDef.Description: List of local datastores with VM. VMs on local datastores are not protected from HA. Also, the physical disks may not be protected with RAID. Suitable for Agent VM, which goes down with the ESXi host.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Network Interfaces
ViewDef.Description: List the summary of the network properties associated with the Distributed Virtual Switch for the selected Host System in your environment.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Unavailable
ViewDef.Description: List of ESXi hosts that are not available for a variety of reasons (disconnected, unresponsive, in maintenance mode, powered off, and in quarantine) Oowered off ESXi should be taken out of vCenter and physically decommissioned. This will save licenses from all vendors.

ViewDef.Title: vSphere Distributed Switch Inventory
ViewDef.Description: Lists vSphere Distributed Switches with necessary information for inventory purpose.

ViewDef.Title: ESXi Distribution by Storage Path Counts
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of ESXi storage paths. Ideally, it's consistent across all ESXi hosts, with >1 active paths. ESXi hosts in the same cluster should have identical configuration.

ViewDef.Title: VM Distribution by CPU Size
ViewDef.Description: Relative distribution of VMs by vCPU. They are not sorted by values, but by the most common values.
